title: pingu39
author: pingu39
content: What do you think about the new exchange Bitget, which is advertised by Messi.Do you think it is trustworthy.They have good and attractive promotions.Otherwise, there are many new exchange offices that appear every day. This one seems ok to me.What do you think.

comments.author: Potato Chips
comments.body: Those two are the last thing I'd consider when it comes to picking an exchange since they can always pay the popular bunch to advertise for them and there's always a catch when it comes to promotions - I suggest looking into every promos terms before jumping.Gotta say, I'm not that familiar with this exchange nor buy half of their reported volume. But if we're talking about general usage, there should be better places out there even for no-mandatory kyc full fledged exchanges.

comments.author: Cryptoababe
comments.body: For me, Bitget isnt a bad exchange. But I wont advise you to Fully rely on any centralised exchange. There are some exchanges with reserve which they are still a bit reliable than ones with no reserve. You can check Defillama.com for exchanges with Merkel Tree or Reserve. Although, not all exchanges are updated there. Even some are with reserve but Defillama is yet to update them.

comments.author: joniboini
comments.body: Quote from: Sarah Azhari on March 12, 2023, 02:21:51 AMI just heard about Bitget today, and when I searched it, Bitget doesn't listed on my Ministry of Trade country, so I will avoid it.The list you're referring to also doesn't include Binance afaik, so it is not the best list if you want to compare the "trustworthiness" or reliability of an exchange. Most of them need active registration plus an office in the country, so it is understandable that some big exchanges would rather 'ignore' it and just use a proxy to get customers from the local market (like Tokocrypto and Binance for example). Still, I've never heard anyone mention Bitget either, so their marketing is certainly lacking for some markets. CMIIW.Quote from: Jawhead999 on March 12, 2023, 05:32:34 AMThere's no way to verify any centralized exchange, trade Bitcoin P2P with other person is also need a trust since you need to make the person will send his coins when you've send your coins first. The only way is using decentralized exchange or P2P which act as an escrow.Other than making sure we visit the right address and judge whether a statement is wrong or not (which includes many things, such as marketing materials), I also think it is hard to 'verify' an exchange. A better term is probably to look for reviews from other members, or try it with a throwaway account if possible before you decide to use it as one of your main exchanges. It is impossible to remove trust completely, but at the very least we should be able to control our funds even if the platform we use went bust. I don't think an exchange fits that criterion though.

comments.author: Edwardard
comments.body: Personally I dont try a lot of exchanges for my personal trading (I am only a binance and bybit user), but I did try bitget before because of some deposit bonus offers ofc, lol. I must say their customer support is very quick in responding and solving queries. I had a long conversation with them regarding some issue and they were responding everytime. You can trade with some amount in this exchange, especially their native token, which is quite volatile  They are not upto the mark for P2P trading yet (atleast for me). Still using binance for p2p.However, I never go all in on any exchange, always diversify to be SAFU.I suggest you to move this thread to "exchanges" board.
